The public health measures associated COVID-19 have induced many challenges for older adults, caregivers, and healthcare providers. Gerontechnology-such as information and communication technologies, robots, telehealth, wearable technologies, remote sensors, and Internet of Things-can assist older people and caregivers to cope with the pandemic.

body_text.text: Although people of all ages are at risk of contracting the COVID-19, figures clearly 3 showed that people over the age of 60 are more susceptible to the disease and presented 4 the highest mortality 1 . Aggressive containment measures, such as national lockdown, 5 social distancing, and quarantine have been placed by many countries to mitigate the 6 spread of the contagious disease. Strict public health measures can protect older people 7 against infection, but may inadvertently induce negative consequences, including 8 social isolation, limited access to routine health and social care services, and poor 9 self-health management. FIGREF0.text: 14 and communication technologies (ICTs) are promising tools to respond to this 15 challenge. The utilization of existing and free communication platforms (such as 16 WhatsApp, FaceTime, Zoom, WeChat) allow older adults to remain physically distant 17 but emotionally connected. Systematic reviews have revealed that Internet and 18 mobile-based apps, companion robots, video games (Wii and TV gaming systems), video calls, and general computer usage are effective tools to reduce social isolation 20 and loneliness for older adults in the short-term 2, 3 . ICT can alleviate social isolation 21 through the development of a sense of connection, maintenance of existing 22 relationships, gain social support, engagement in activities of interests, and 23 enhancement of self-confidence 4 . Companion robots, such as Paro, can be used for 24 isolated and agitated residents living in nursing homes or long-term care facilities when 25 they couldn't have any visitors and remain confined in their rooms during the 26 pandemic 5 . 27 Traditional health and social care services, depending on physical proximity and 28 in-person care, are challenged by the pandemic. Older people have none or limited 29 access to routine home care services, community supports, and medical care during 30 social distancing and/or lockdown. Homebound and containment may further increase 31 sedentary behavior and nutritional challenge, contributing to frailty and functional 32 decline. Telehealth, through platforms as online forums, video conferencing, virtual 33 reality, robotics, and mobile integrated health care programs, enables a person to 34 receive consultations and/or health and social care over distance 6 . Together with 35 wearable devices, remote monitoring sensors, and other technologies like the 36 Internet of Things, formal and informal caregivers can be alerted to the changes of the 37 health status (physical activity, sleep, anxiety or stress level, nutrition) as well as travel 38 GERONTECHNOLOGY IN PANDEMIC 3 and exposure history of a person. Accordingly, personalized intervention work can be 39 delivered including messaging with reminders to hand hygiene, take medication, 40 physical exercises, or grocery/medication delivery; and appropriate resources and 41 healthcare (para)professionals could be automatically connected. 42 Technology can, to a large extent, assist older adults and caregivers in response to 43 this pandemic, and enhance the well-being moving forward. Nevertheless, limited 44 access to technology and a wide variation in technology literacy within older people 45 should be noted. The "digital divide" still exists for disadvantaged older adults with low 46 education and income 7 . The COVID-19 is an alarming bell, reminding us urgent 47 attention should be paid to improve technology literacy among older people, as well as 48 support caregivers and health professionals to use technological innovations as a 49 complementary tool for delivering care services.50
